### Prerequisite

In this text, we will continue exploring the boundaries between literature and science. For this reason, we recommend reading the previous text (<htcite0>).

### Introduction

During our school years, we learn to name everything around us through words. As we advance in our studies, we realize that these words sometimes have more than one meaning. Depending on the family’s financial situation, if a person has the opportunity to continue studying, they may also discover that the meanings of words change over time (<htcite0>).

This lack of knowledge can lead us to make different interpretation errors, which brings us to our first reflection:

Reflection 1: I Was Mistaken

Have you ever used current knowledge to interpret events from the past, only to later realize that you misunderstood the text?

Have you ever thought that a word you use every day might not have the same meaning it had thousands of years ago?

### Definition

Before studying some specific cases of anachronism, we must clearly define what anachronism means. To do this, we turn to the Britannica Dictionary (<htcite0>):
• 1. something (such as a word, an object, or an event) that is mistakenly placed in a time where it does not belong in a story, movie, etc.

Practice 1: I Wasn’t There
We are now in the year .

Now, take a sheet of paper and a pen, and describe how you witnessed the first arrival of K’inich Yax K’uk’ Mo’ when he took control of Copán, in Honduras (Abya Yala), around the year (Hutnick, Anastasia, , pp. 36; History Tracers Team, , Indígenas Copán).

**Practice 1** presents a possible anachronism if the text is written as a newspaper article or magazine report, as if you had actually witnessed the event. This occurs because, for someone to have seen the conquest of Copán, they would have had to be born before the year <htdate0>—and if still alive today, they would be over <spam id="iage"></spam> years old.

On the other hand, if **Practice 1** is written in the form of a poem or short story, the account would not be considered an anachronism, since it would involve a kind of abstraction that is common in literature (<htcite0>).

### A World “Victim” of Anachronism

In different sections of *History Tracers*, we have discussed the planet we live on and have tried to better understand it.

One of the most common anachronisms observed among students and adults occurs when, upon encountering the words “world” or “earth” in ancient texts, they conclude that people in the past understood the planet exactly as we do today. In light of this, we will take a “journey into the past” to understand what “world” really meant in ancient times.

#### The Modern World

The modern world is studied in detail in the *History Tracers Atlas* (<htcite0>). From this atlas, we use **Figure 1**, which shows the continent of Antarctica, located at the southernmost point of Earth, with the regions of South America (*Abya Yala*), Africa, and Australia also visible. This image was produced by the Mapswire project (<htcite1>).
Figure 1: Antártica. © Mapswire ().

In this image, we can see that our planet has an approximately spherical shape, known as an ellipsoid, with a radius of 6,378.137 kilometers at the Equator (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). The planet contains various continents, which we humans have artificially divided into countries, states, and cities.

This is a relatively recent understanding. As we go back in time, we notice that the model of the planet was directly linked to knowledge of specific regions.

#### Different Views

When discussing the concept of “world,” we must specify not only the historical period but also the geographical region being referred to.

Looking at Africa and the Middle East, for example, we know that Eratosthenes, in Egypt, measured the Earth’s dimensions, offering for the first time the idea that the planet had a spherical shape (<htcite2>). More than a thousand years later, Al-Biruni measured the Earth’s radius again, this time using a lunar eclipse (<htcite3>; <htcite4>; <htcit5>).

Information about the Earth’s sphericity and size spread to nearby regions, such as Europe, even before Columbus’s voyages (<htcite0>).

Moving away from Eurasia and Africa, however, we find that beliefs and cultural constructions reveal a very different understanding of the world. During the same period when the spherical Earth model was being consolidated, in Mesoamerica (*Abya Yala*), the universe was still understood as being divided into levels — underworld, world, and heavens — (<htcite1>). This worldview can be observed in the Ball Games, such as the one shown in **Figure 3**, found throughout Mesoamerica. (*Abya Yala*).
Figure 3: View of the “Ball Game” of Copán, Honduras. Photo taken on , during a site visit.

#### Going Further Back in Time

The Mesoamerican worldview was also present in even earlier times in the Middle East, as shown by ancient Sumerian texts. These writings claimed that one could reach the “heavens” by climbing something large, like a tree (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>).

#### How Do Anachronisms Occur?

After presenting these facts, we can conclude that anachronism occurs when:
- When reading references to “world” and “underworld” in Mesoamerica, we assume that these peoples understood the planet as spherical and the universe as we know it today.
- When we state that “we have known the world is spherical since <htdate0>...”, without considering that communication in the past was much slower and contact among peoples very limited — making generalizations incorrect.
- When interpreting references to “world” in Middle Eastern or European texts written before Eratosthenes’s measurements as equivalent to our modern concept of the planet.

The last case of anachronism becomes clear when we superimpose the ancient Babylonian world map onto the modern world map (**Figura 4**). It is evident that the Babylonian depiction represents a local world, not the entire planet as we conceive it today (<htcite4>; <htcite5>; <htcite6>; <htcite7>).

### Conclusion

In this text, we studied the concept of anachronism, applying it in different examples.

In addition to explicitly mentioning anachronism, the text also highlights the importance of analyzing when a text was written and what was known at the time its authors composed it — topics often studied alongside mathematics.

Starting with the next text, we will explore how mathematics helps us understand written texts and how, by improving our reading comprehension, we can better solve mathematical problems.

exercise_v2.question: Can we use recent knowledge and claim it was known thousands of years ago?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: In this text, we studied two types of anachronism: one related to ourselves and another focused on the concept of “world.” In the latter case, we learned that humanity’s understanding of the world and its boundaries has changed greatly over the millennia; therefore, we cannot project today’s knowledge onto a distant past.

exercise_v2.question: Is our current understanding of the world the same as that of the past?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo:
If we consider only the place we live in as human beings, we could say that over the past millions of years it has remained more or less the same. However, when we study the Earth in greater depth, we find that in the past, the continents and the planet’s configuration were very different from what we know today.
Although writing emerged relatively recently in our history, in that short span of time our perception of what the “world” is —as opposed to what it actually is— has changed profoundly.
